data.title: CrossFit MINS Workout
data.text: Workout of the Day 26.10.2025 WODDAILYSWEAT For Quality 6 Rounds 3:00 Row/Ski Erg 20 Box Stepups 15 Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift High Pulls (24/16) 10 Ring Rows Sweat: 16/8 Train: 20/12 Compete: 24/16"
data.full_text:
Workout of the Day

26.10.2025

WOD
DAILYSWEAT


For Quality
6 Rounds
3:00 Row/Ski Erg
20 Box Stepups
15 Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift High Pulls (24/16)
10 Ring Rows


Sweat: 16/8
Train: 20/12
Compete: 24/16"

ai_explanation.explanation:
Workout Overview


Hey everyone! Today’s WOD is all about quality and consistency, focusing on building endurance and strength through a series of movements that will challenge your cardiovascular system and muscular endurance. We’ll be doing 6 rounds of rowing or skiing, followed by box step-ups, kettlebell sumo deadlift high pulls, and ring rows. The goal here is to maintain good form throughout each round while managing your pace to complete all 6 rounds effectively.


Workout Components


1. Row/Ski Erg (3:00)

  • **Technique Steps**:
  • If you're on the rower, sit tall with your feet secured and grab the handle with an overhand grip.
  • Start with your knees bent and your arms extended, then push through your heels, extending your legs while pulling the handle towards your chest.
  • Finish with your elbows drawn back and your back straight, then return to the starting position in a controlled manner.
  • If you're on the Ski Erg, stand tall, grip the handles, and initiate the movement by pulling down with your arms while driving your knees slightly forward.

  • **Form Tips**:
  • Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the movement.
  • Focus on a smooth, powerful stroke rather than rushing through it.
  • For the Ski Erg, use your legs to drive the movement, not just your arms.

  • **Scaling/Modifications**:
  • If you’re new to rowing or skiing, reduce the time to 2:00 or even 1:30 to focus on form.
  • Consider using a lower resistance setting on the Ski Erg for a more manageable pace.

    • 2. Box Step-Ups (20 reps)

  • **Technique Steps**:
  • Stand facing the box with your feet hip-width apart.
  • Step up onto the box with one foot, pressing through your heel to lift your body up.
  • Bring your other foot up to meet the first on top of the box, then step back down one foot at a time.

  • **Form Tips**:
  • Keep your chest up and engage your core to maintain balance.
  • Ensure your entire foot is on the box to avoid slipping.

  • **Scaling/Modifications**:
  • Use a lower box if you’re still building strength or balance.
  • If you have knee issues, consider doing step-ups without weights or using a bench.

    • 3. Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift High Pulls (15 reps)

  • **Technique Steps**:
  • Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out, and the kettlebell on the ground between your feet.
  • Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grab the kettlebell with both hands.
  • Drive through your heels to stand up, pulling the kettlebell up along your body, leading with your elbows.
  • At the top of the movement, your elbows should be higher than your wrists, and the kettlebell should be close to your chin.

  • **Form Tips**:
  • Keep your back straight and chest up during the lift.
  • Use your legs to initiate the movement, not just your arms.

  • **Scaling/Modifications**:
  • Use a lighter kettlebell if you’re new to this movement or if you’re feeling fatigued.
  • If kettlebells aren’t available, you can substitute with dumbbells.

    • 4. Ring Rows (10 reps)

  • **Technique Steps**:
  • Set the rings at a height that allows you to lean back with your arms extended while keeping your feet on the ground.
  • Grab the rings with an overhand grip, lean back, and keep your body straight.
  • Pull your chest towards the rings by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together.

  • **Form Tips**:
  • Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
  • Avoid using momentum; focus on a controlled pull.

  • **Scaling/Modifications**:
  • If rings are too challenging, you can perform inverted rows on a barbell or use a TRX system.
  • Adjust the height of the rings to make it easier or harder based on your strength level.

    • Loading and Rep-Modification Options


  • **Sweat**:
  • Row/Ski: 2:00
  • Box Step-Ups: 16/8 (no weights)
  • Kettlebell: 16kg/8kg
  • Ring Rows: 8 reps

  • **Train**:
  • Row/Ski: 3:00
  • Box Step-Ups: 20 reps (light weight if needed)
  • Kettlebell: 20kg/12kg
  • Ring Rows: 10 reps

  • **Compete**:
  • Row/Ski: 3:00
  • Box Step-Ups: 24/16 (with weights)
  • Kettlebell: 24kg/16kg
  • Ring Rows: 10 reps

    • Strategy Advice

  • Focus on maintaining a steady pace throughout the workout. It’s better to go slower and keep good form than to rush and risk injury.
  • Break up the movements into manageable sets if you start to feel fatigued, especially on the kettlebell high pulls and ring rows.
  • Remember to breathe and stay hydrated! You’ve got this!

combined_content.title: CrossFit MINS Workout
combined_content.workout_text:
WOD:

For Quality

6 Rounds:

  • 3:00 Row/Ski Erg
  • 20 Box Step-ups
  • 15 Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift High Pulls (24/16)
  • 10 Ring Rows

    • Sweat: 16/8

    Train: 20/12

    Compete: 24/16

--- AI EXPLANATION --- ## Workout Overview Hey everyone! Today’s WOD is all about quality and consistency, focusing on building endurance and strength through a series of movements that will challenge your cardiovascular system and muscular endurance. We’ll be doing 6 rounds of rowing or skiing, followed by box step-ups, kettlebell sumo deadlift high pulls, and ring rows. The goal here is to maintain good form throughout each round while managing your pace to complete all 6 rounds effectively. ## Workout Components ### 1. Row/Ski Erg (3:00) - **Technique Steps**: - If you're on the rower, sit tall with your feet secured and grab the handle with an overhand grip. - Start with your knees bent and your arms extended, then push through your heels, extending your legs while pulling the handle towards your chest. - Finish with your elbows drawn back and your back straight, then return to the starting position in a controlled manner. - If you're on the Ski Erg, stand tall, grip the handles, and initiate the movement by pulling down with your arms while driving your knees slightly forward. - **Form Tips**: - Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the movement. - Focus on a smooth, powerful stroke rather than rushing through it. - For the Ski Erg, use your legs to drive the movement, not just your arms. - **Scaling/Modifications**: - If you’re new to rowing or skiing, reduce the time to 2:00 or even 1:30 to focus on form. - Consider using a lower resistance setting on the Ski Erg for a more manageable pace. ### 2. Box Step-Ups (20 reps) - **Technique Steps**: - Stand facing the box with your feet hip-width apart. - Step up onto the box with one foot, pressing through your heel to lift your body up. - Bring your other foot up to meet the first on top of the box, then step back down one foot at a time. - **Form Tips**: - Keep your chest up and engage your core to maintain balance. - Ensure your entire foot is on the box to avoid slipping. - **Scaling/Modifications**: - Use a lower box if you’re still building strength or balance. - If you have knee issues, consider doing step-ups without weights or using a bench. ### 3. Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift High Pulls (15 reps) - **Technique Steps**: - Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out, and the kettlebell on the ground between your feet. - Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grab the kettlebell with both hands. - Drive through your heels to stand up, pulling the kettlebell up along your body, leading with your elbows. - At the top of the movement, your elbows should be higher than your wrists, and the kettlebell should be close to your chin. - **Form Tips**: - Keep your back straight and chest up during the lift. - Use your legs to initiate the movement, not just your arms. - **Scaling/Modifications**: - Use a lighter kettlebell if you’re new to this movement or if you’re feeling fatigued. - If kettlebells aren’t available, you can substitute with dumbbells. ### 4. Ring Rows (10 reps) - **Technique Steps**: - Set the rings at a height that allows you to lean back with your arms extended while keeping your feet on the ground. - Grab the rings with an overhand grip, lean back, and keep your body straight. - Pull your chest towards the rings by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together. - **Form Tips**: - Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. - Avoid using momentum; focus on a controlled pull. - **Scaling/Modifications**: - If rings are too challenging, you can perform inverted rows on a barbell or use a TRX system. - Adjust the height of the rings to make it easier or harder based on your strength level. ## Loading and Rep-Modification Options - **Sweat**: - Row/Ski: 2:00 - Box Step-Ups: 16/8 (no weights) - Kettlebell: 16kg/8kg - Ring Rows: 8 reps - **Train**: - Row/Ski: 3:00 - Box Step-Ups: 20 reps (light weight if needed) - Kettlebell: 20kg/12kg - Ring Rows: 10 reps - **Compete**: - Row/Ski: 3:00 - Box Step-Ups: 24/16 (with weights) - Kettlebell: 24kg/16kg - Ring Rows: 10 reps ### Strategy Advice - Focus on maintaining a steady pace throughout the workout. It’s better to go slower and keep good form than to rush and risk injury. - Break up the movements into manageable sets if you start to feel fatigued, especially on the kettlebell high pulls and ring rows. - Remember to breathe and stay hydrated! You’ve got this!
